clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Muscle Strength by Transcutaneous Electrical Stimulation
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Muscle Strength by Transcutaneous Electrical Stimulation in Intensive Care Unit Patients

lead_sponsor.agency: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Saint Etienne

clinical_study.source: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Saint Etienne

brief_summary.textblock:
Intensive care unit acquired muscle weakness (ICUAW), a common disease characterized by damage to the peripheral nervous system and/or muscles, is a serious condition with significant morbidity and mortality.
The diagnosis of ICUAW is difficult and often delayed, because based upon clinical assessment of muscle strength (MRC score), requiring patients to be awake and cooperative.
Transcutaneous electrical stimulation consists in applying electrical stimulation along a motor nerve in order to generate muscle contraction. The mechanical response thus generated is recorded, which allows to appreciate the generated muscular strength. This noninvasive procedure, which can easily be performed at the bedside, could represent an interesting tool to evaluate muscle strength, in ICU patients under deep sedation.

primary_outcome.description: Reproducibility of the force measurement after muscle stimulation by a doublet at 100 Hz.

secondary_outcome.description: Reproducibility of the force measurement after muscle stimulation by a doublet at 10 Hz.

secondary_outcome.measure: Intensive care unit acquired muscle weakness (ICUAW)
secondary_outcome.description: Occurrence of ICUAW defined by a MRC score less than 48

intervention.description: Patient will have the day of inclusion and then again after 20 minutes in finally, 72 hours (3 days) later : Increasing electrical stimulation until muscle contraction three simple electrical stimulations, three doublets (ie 2 very close electrical stimulations) at frequency 10Hz three doublets at the frequency of 100Hz electrical stimulation leading to a maximum contraction of the muscle (called "tetanus"),

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age ≥ 18 years
- Deeply sedated (Riker 1-2), admitted in intensive care unit B of ST-Etienne hospital
- Patient whose family has given informed and written consent to the patient's participation in the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant woman,
- Patients with peripheral nerve damage prior to or at the time of measurement
- Curarized patients (non-efficacy of neurostimulation)
- Fracture of limb or pelvis
- Presence of a catheter in the stimulation zone (femoral artery or vein)
